event.title: Teach For America
event.shortdesc: Phi Sigma Pi is raising awareness of educational inequity and promoting Teach For America by hosting a speaker and showing the movie, The Lottery.

fulldesc.p:
Educational inequity prevents children from fulfilling their potential. It limits life choices, professional options, and incomes, and weakens families and communities. Because children in low-income communities are predominantly children of color, they also face the added burden of societal low expectations and discrimination.
That's where Teach For America comes in!
Teach For America provides a critical source of well-trained t-eachers who are helping break the cycle of educational inequity. These teachers, called corps members, commit to teach for two years in one of 39 urban and rural regions across the country, going above and beyond traditional expectations to help their students to achieve at high levels.
Rachel Martin, a recent graduate of Millersville University, is one of these teachers. Rachel will be here to speak about her experiences with TFA as well as TFA as a whole.
After Rachel's talk, the 2010 film The Lottery will be shown. The Lottery uncovers the failures of the traditional public school system and reveals that hundreds of thousands of parents attempt to flee the system every year. The Lottery follows four of these families from Harlem and the Bronx who have entered their children in a charter school lottery. Out of thousands of hopefuls, only a small minority will win the chance of a better future.
Refreshments will be served!

event.title: GODSPELL: Presented by The All Campus Musical Org.
event.shortdesc: The All Campus Musical Organization (ACMO) Presents GODSPELL

fulldesc.p: Millersville University's All Campus Music Organization (ACMO) Presents: GODSPELL, a student directed and produced production.
Conceived and originally directed by John-Michael Tebelak, with music and new lyrics by Stephen Schwartz, "Godspell" is one of the biggest off-Broadway and Broadway successes of all time.

Plot Summary: Based on the Gospel According to St. Matthew, and featuring a sparkling score by Stephen Schwartz, "Godspell" boasts a string of well-loved songs, led by the international hit, "Day By Day." As the cast performs "Prepare Ye The Way Of The Lord," "Learn Your Lessons Well," "All For The Best," "All Good Gifts," "Turn Back, O Man" and "By My Side," the parables of Jesus Christ come humanly and hearteningly to life.
Rafters Theatre, Dutcher Hall, Millersville University
GODSPELL is presented by special arrangement with Music Theatre International (MTI)
$10.00 General Admission
$7.00 MU ID, Senior Citizens and Other Students
$5.00 MU ID super saver advance sales only at the SMC, room 103

p.strong: Tickets can be purchased Mon-Fri, 8 a.m. - 4 p.m. at the SMC, room 103 or by calling 717-872-3811 and online at www.MUTicketsOnline.com.

event.title: Ville After Dark: The Hangover
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark Movie: The Hangover

fulldesc.p: Plot Summary: Angelenos Doug Billings and Tracy Garner are about to get married. Two days before the wedding, the four men in the wedding party - Doug, Doug's two best buddies Phil Wenneck and Stu Price, and Tracy's brother Alan Garner - hop into Tracy's father's beloved Mercedes convertible for a 24-hour stag party to Las Vegas. Phil, a married high school teacher, has the same maturity level as his students when he's with his pals. Stu, a dentist, is worried about everything, especially what his controlling girlfriend Melissa thinks. Because she disapproves of traditional male bonding rituals, Stu has to lie to her about the stag, he telling her that they are going on a wine tasting tour in the Napa Valley. Regardless, he intends on eventually marrying her, against the advice and wishes of his friends. And Alan seems to be unaware of what are considered the social graces of the western world. The morning after their arrival in Las Vegas, they awaken in their hotel suite each with the worst hangover. None remembers what happened in the past twelve or so hours. The suite is in shambles. And certain things are in the suite that shouldn't be, and certain things that should be in the suite are missing. Probably the most important in the latter category is Doug. As Phil, Stu and Alan try to find Doug using only what little pieces of information they have at hand, they go on a journey of discovery of how certain things got into the suite and what happened to the missing items. However they are on a race for time as if they can't find Doug in the next few hours, they are going to have to explain to Tracy why they are not yet back in Los Angeles. And even worse, they may not find Doug at all before the wedding.

p.em: This event is part of the Ville After Dark Spring Programming. Please contact the Student Programs Office if you would like more information at 717-872-3506.

event.title: Ville After Dark: No Strings Attached
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark Movie - No Strings Attached

fulldesc.p: Plot Summary: Lifelong friends Adam (Ashton Kutcher) and Emma (Natalie Portman) attempt to avoid falling in love after falling into each other's beds in this comedy exploring the complexities and quirks of having friends with benefits. Adam was a typical, hormonal 14 year old when he first came on to Emma at summer camp -- and got shot down in flames. In the years that followed, however, Adam and Emma continued to cross paths until eventually, they both caved to their animal instincts. Despite an intense session of earth-shaking sex, however, Emma makes it clear to Adam that the last thing she wants is a committed relationship. And thanks to the fact that Adam's father (Kevin Kline), a fallen television star, has just begun dating his son's ex-girlfriend, the horrified bachelor has developed an aversion to monogamy as well. At first their casual stance on sex works great for both; Emma can focus on her career instead of allowing her emotions to dictate her decisions, and Adam can play the field without fear of hurting her feelings. Over, time, however, a funny thing happens -- Adam began to develop feelings for Emma that he never had for any of his countless conquests. Before they both know it, love has reared its ugly head and they've gotten too emotionally involved to cut the relationship off cold. But is commitment in the cards for the couple that always swore it would never get serious, or has the time come for them to finally part ways once and for all?
This event is part of the Ville After Dark Spring Programming. Please contact the Student Programs Office if you would like more information at 717-872-3506.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Memento
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents: Memento

fulldesc.p:
Description: Christopher Nolan's Memento tells the story of bereaved husband Leonard, who is deprived of his memory and lives his snippets of life to avenge his murdered wife. The scenes of the main storyline unfold backwards, keeping spectators curious about how time and memory interrelate. Spectators learn that Leonard actively remixes his present to his own emotional advantage.
Like "Mr. Nobody," the film's creative structure engages spectators to create the film, exercising their imaginations with the potential structures the film's story could take.
Discussant: Dr. Lowery Woodall, Assistant Professor of Communications and Theater
Sponsors: The University Theme Committee and The Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences

The Reflect & Connect series involves a discussion around a short and interesting text about community service where students, faculty, staff, and community members can come together, reflect on service, share those reflections with others, and then sign up to connect to the community through volunteer opportunities.

event.title: Jeff Johnson: A Public Lecture
event.shortdesc: Jeff Johnson is a Washington, D.C. based award-winning journalist, social activist and political commentator.

fulldesc.p: Description: Jeff Johnson, a Washington, D.C. based award-winning journalist, social activist and political commentator will be speaking at Millersville University, April 20, at 7:30 p.m. This event will take place on campus in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.

Biography: From his celebrated conversations with marquee world figures in the political, business and entertainment arenas to his grass-roots trench work to inspire the next generation of leaders; investigative journalist, political correspondent and activist, Johnson continues to be a trailblazing social entrepreneur and authentic voice for change.

Johnson spent the last decade merging the worlds of politics and popular culture including his work as Senior Advisor for Media and Youth Outreach for People for the American Way, National Director of the Youth & College division of the NAACP and an appointment by Russell Simmons as the Vice President of the Hip Hop Summit Action Network (HSAN).
Johnson consistently challenges audiences to innovatively weigh solutions to resolve historic and systemic social imbalances and inequalities.

p.strong: This event is free and open to the public. No tickets required.

As the cast performs "Prepare Ye The Way Of The Lord," "Learn Your Lessons Well," "All For The Best," "All Good Gifts," "Turn Back, O Man" and "By My Side," the parables of Jesus Christ come humanly and hearteningly to life.
Rafters Theatre, Dutcher Hall, Millersville University

event.title: Guest Artist Sonia Lee, Harpsichord
event.shortdesc: Millersville's music department presents guest artist Sonia Lee, harpsichord.

fulldesc.p: Description: As part of the spring 2011 piano symposium, the Department of Music at Millersville University welcomes Sonia Lee, harpsichord, as a guest artist, April 26. Lee will be on campus, in the Form Atrium of McComsey Hall from 2:30-3:30 p.m. for workshops with music classes, followed by a recital at 7 p.m.
This program features harpsichord music of the French clavecinistes and the North German school, as well as a work for flute or harpsichord by J.S. Bach.

Artist Bio: As an award-winning early keyboardist, Lee, has been praised by critics for her "very high standard of playing" and her ability "to dazzle an enraptured audience." She has been heard as soloist at festivals as well as regional and international conferences.

As a continuo player on both harpsichord and organ, she has collaborated with numerous soloists and ensembles. An advocate of contemporary harpsichord music, she has performed works by such prize-winning composers as Dagmar Feyen, James Dorsa, Asako Hirabayashi, and Luis Mucillo. The recipient of numerous awards and grants, Lee is a laureate of the Montreal Baroque Galaxie-CBC Rising Star Competition, the Mae and Irving Jurow International Harpsichord Competition, the Canadian Music Competitions and the William E. Gribbons Award sponsored by the American Musical Instrument Society.
Currently, she is on the adjunct music history faculty at Illinois Wesleyan University.

event.title: International Film Screening: "Only When I Dance"
event.shortdesc: Millersville University Library presents an international film screening of "Only When I Dance."

fulldesc.p: Description: Millersville University Library presents a screening of the international film "Only When I Dance," Friday, April 29 at 7 p.m. This event will take place in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.

Be sure to stick around for a second screening at 9 p.m. of the international film "Jaffa."
This event, which is free and open to the public, is presented by the Millersville University Library and co-sponsored by the Foreign Languages Department and the MU Cine Club.
Film Synopsis: ONLY WHEN I DANCE, a film by Beadie Finzi. This feel-good documentary follows Irlan and Isabela, two teenagers from the violent favelas of Rio de Janeiro, as they pursue their dreams of becoming professional ballet dancers. This inspiring story takes us from Rio - where their communities must raise the funds to support their ambitions - to exhilarating ballet competitions in New York and Switzerland. It's a film about their determination to dance, and the price one must pay for talent, ambition and success.

event.title: Ville After Dark: Baby Wants Candy
event.shortdesc: Ville After Dark Presents: Baby Wants Candy

fulldesc.p: Baby Wants Candy (BWC) asks the audience for a title of a musical that has never been performed before. The first title they hear then becomes the title and basis for that evening's 60 minute completely improvised musical. BWC is accompanied by a full band.

BWC was founded in Chicago in 1997 and has performed over 1,400 completely improvised musicals to sold-out crowds from Singapore to Edinburgh. BWC has featured performers like Stephanie Weir and Nicole Parker (MadTV), Rachel Dratch and Jack McBrayer (30 Rock), Al Samuels and Kevin Fleming (Sports Action Team), Peter Gwinn (Colbert Report), Garry Tallent (Bruce Springsteen and the E St Band), and Mark Pender (Max Weinberg 7) to name a few. BWC has become a talent pool of some of the nation's strongest musical and comedic talent.
This event is part of the Ville After Dark Spring Programming. Please contact the Student Programs Office if you would like more information at 717-872-3506.

event.title: International Film Screening: "Jaffa"
event.shortdesc: Millersville University Library presents a screening of the international film "Jaffa."

fulldesc.p: Description: Millersville University Library presents a screening of the international film "Jaffa," Friday, April 29 at 9 p.m. This event will take place in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.
Come early for a 7 p.m. screening of the international film "Only When I Dance."
This event, which is free and open to the public, is presented by the Millersville University Library and co-sponsored by the Foreign Languages Department and the MU Cine Club.

Film Synopsis: JAFFA, a film by Keren Yedaya. In the heart of the Israeli city of Jaffa, Reuven's garage is a family-run business. The garage workers consist of Reuven's beautiful daughter Mali, his aggressive and distant son Meir, as well as the young Palestinian man, Toufik. No one suspects that Mali and Toufik have been in love for years, and that Mali is pregnant with Toufik's child. As the two lovers secretly make their wedding arrangements, tension steadily builds between Toufik and Meir, who openly voices his disdain and prejudices about Arabs. As these relationships continue to intensify, emotions begin to boil, resulting in an astonishing conclusion.

event.title: Spring 2011 Graduate Commencement Ceremony
event.shortdesc: Millersville's graduate ceremony will be in Pucillo Gymnasium for students graduating with a master's degree and/or post-bachelor's teacher certification.

fulldesc.p: This spring, Millersville will be hosting a graduation ceremony celebrating graduate achievements.
The graduate ceremony will be held on Friday, May 6 at 6:30 p.m. in Pucillo Gymnasium for students graduating with a master's degree and/or post-bachelor's teacher certification.
For Friday's graduate commencement, Dr. Thomas P. Bell,'83, current president of the International Technology and Engineering Educators Association, will be the speaker.
The celebration occurring after the graduate ceremony will be held at Pucillo Gymnasium.
Parking is provided on campus at parking lots and parking garage, however space is limited. The Millersville University police department will be present to help direct traffic.
A live webcast will be available online during the events for those who are unable to attend.
For more information, visit http://www.millersville.edu/commencement or email commencement@millersville.edu.

event.title: War and Peace: Durufle's "Requieme"
event.shortdesc:
Keystone Singers in Concert: War and Peace
Maurice Durufl's "Requiem, Janequin's "La Guerre" and others!
Location: Highland Presbyterian Church, Lancaster
Tickets: $10 - free for ALL students
Tickets may be purchased at the door, at the MU Box Office in the SMC, or at www.muticketsonline.com

fulldesc.p:
Join MU's chamber choir, The Keystone Singers, Dr. Ross Ellison at the organ and Prof. Laurie Reese on cello as they perform one of the 20th century's most beautiful works, Maurice Durufl's Requiem. Included on the program is Janequin's 16th century programatic work, La Guerre, musically depicting King Francis I's victory over the Swiss at the Battle of Marignan in 1515. The work is complete with canon fire, flying arrows, cries of "Kill him! Kill Him!" and the wailing Swiss - "toute belore bigot" - all is lost by God!
Wonderfully contrasting French choral works brought to life by the outstanding voices of the Keystone Singers. Join us!

event.title: Spring 2011 Undergraduate Commencement Ceremony
event.shortdesc: This spring, Millersville will hold their undergraduate ceremony in Biemesderfer Stadium. The director of MIT's biomechatronics lab will give the commencement address.

fulldesc.p: This spring, Millersville will be hosting a graduation ceremony celebrating baccalaureate achievements.
The undergraduate ceremony will be held on Saturday, May 7 at 10 a.m. at Biemesderfer Stadium for students graduating with a baccalaureate degree from spring 2011.

The speaker for Saturday's undergraduate commencement will be Dr. Hugh Herr,'90, considered one of the top biomechatronics researchers in the world. Herr is currently an associate professor and director of the biomechatronics lab at the MIT Media Lab.

Celebrations taking place immediately after the undergraduate ceremony are as follows: the School of Science and Mathematics will meet outside of Caputo Hall/Roddy Science Center; the School of Education will meet at the Osburn circle and the School of Humanities and Social Sciences will meet behind Gerhart Hall, in front of Byerly Hall.
Participants and anyone who will be standing or walking on Chryst Field are required to wear shoes with flat, broad soles. Narrow wedges and narrow heels are strictly prohibited.
Parking is provided on campus at parking lots and parking garage, however space is limited. The Millersville University police department will be present to help direct traffic.
A live webcast will be available online during the events for those who are unable to attend.
For more information, visit http://www.millersville.edu/commencement or email commencement@millersville.edu.

event.title: 27th Annual Gourmet Gala
event.shortdesc: The Historic Preservation Trust's signature fundraising event is scheduled for Sunday, May 22 from 4 - 7 p.m. at Millersville University-Lancaster.

fulldesc.p: The Historic Preservation Trust's signature fundraising event is scheduled for Sunday, May 22 from 4 p.m. - 7 p.m. at Millersville University-Lancaster.

Local restaurants will offer food and beverages and there will be a silent auction stocked with a variety of treasures from many local and independently-owned businesses. Live music will be provided by local jazz trio Board of Education.
Proceeds will support the Sehner-Ellicott-von Hess House Fund (a.k.a. Trust headquarters.)
Tickets are $75 for members and $85 for non-members, and may be purchased by contacting the Trust office at 291-5861. Tickets will also be available at the door for the same price.

The Historic Preservation Trust's mission is to preserve and protect Lancaster County's rich historic and architectural character through education, advocacy and direct action. All proceeds from the Gourmet Gala benefit historic preservation programs and services throughout Lancaster County.

event.title: Multimedia Exhibit in Ganser Gallery
event.shortdesc: Blindfolded walks in the forest are the basis for a new exhibit at Ganser Gallery.

fulldesc.p: Ganser Gallery at Millersville University will host "Experiential Epistemology,"a multimedia installation collaboratively designed by Lancaster-based artist Kevin Lehman and four students from Millersville University's Art and Design Department: Laura Abbott, Morgan Mangiaruga, Kurt Vail and Jenna Wright. The exhibition runs from May 23 - July 1, 2011, and the gallery will host a reception for the artists Friday, June 24 from 5 to 7 p.m.

The collaborators used sensing experiences-blindfolded walks in the forest-as the basis for this installation. The installation attempts to create a similar "awareness experience" in viewers. Ultimately, the piece is a call for our attention, awareness and action in regards to our relationship with nature.

No pedestal pieces or wall hung art for this art installation. The entire Ganser gallery at Millersville University is transformed into the work of art itself: the gallery walls are shifted and the floor is covered with sand, clay, leaves, live plants, and other natural materials. Other atmospheric effects--such as altered lighting, video projections, sound and fans-complete the transformation of the space.

Lehman is a Lancaster artist that owns and operates Kevin Lehman's Pottery. The pottery has grown into a multi-media community art center that housed fifteen artists and offers classes to adults and children. Kevin recently founded the Lancaster Creative Factory that cultivates creative by providing arts and crafts outreach to underserviced youth and adults in the community. He is also working towards his Masters of Fine Arts degree at the University of the Arts in Philadelphia.He finds collaborations to be a crucial part of his artwork, "For me, the whole idea with collaborations are about community: coming together and working together to solve larger problems."

Ganser Gallery is located on Millersville University, just off the lobby of the Ganser Library. Gallery hours are Monday - Friday, 8:30 a.m. - 4 p.m. All Ganser Gallery Events are free and open to the public. Free tours of the exhibition may be scheduled by calling Ty Clever, Gallery Director: 717-871-2186. Email: tyler.clever@millersville.edu

event.title: The First Arts Celebration
event.shortdesc: McCaskey Young Artist Exhibit at Millersville University - Lancaster.

fulldesc.p: The first weekend in June, Millersville University's President's Commission on Cultural Diversity and Inclusion is presenting "The First Arts Celebration," with a McCaskey High School Art Exhibit and annual Community Concert, featuring Imani's Edu-Tainers African Dance Company. Both events will be held at Millersville University-Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster.

"The First Arts Celebration" begins Friday, June 3, from 5-8 p.m. The McCaskey young Artist Exhibit, hosted by Millersville University, features students' works of art. The exhibition gives students a chance to exhibit their artwork in a professional setting and an opportunity to share their artwork with the community. The exhibition is prepared by McCaskey's art faculty and Millersville University's art and design faculty.

In addition to the art exhibition, on Saturday, June 4, at 7 p.m., Imani's Edu-Tainers African Dance Company will present the 16th annual Community Concert. Imani is the only organization in the Lancaster County area to offer training, education and cultural enrichment in African traditions. It is a nonprofit organization, promoting community awareness, appreciation and understanding of African culture. The concert features authentic traditional dances, costumes and music of West Africa.

Tickets for the Imani dance performance are $15 for adults and $10 for students and seniors. Tickets can be purchased online at www.MUTicketsOnline.com, at the SMC Ticket Office, by calling the ticket office at 717-872-3811 or at MU-Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Monday through Friday 8 a.m.-4:30 p.m.

For more information about the Art Exhibition, contact Nancy Mata, associate professor of art and design, at Nancy.Mata@millersville.edu or by phone, at 717-871-5718. For more information about the Imani African Dance Company, visit www.imaniafricandance.org.

event.location: Millersville University-Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster

event.title: First Friday in June
event.shortdesc:
Latino/Hispanic Art Show: Artwork from some of the best local Latino Artists along with the works of many talented J.P. McCaskey High School art students.
Singer/Songwriter Showcase featuring Bess Rogers and Rachel Platten

fulldesc.p:
Both events are FREE and open to the public.
Bess Rogers
Is Bess Rogers a folkie with pop rock instincts or a pop rocker with an acoustic bent? It's hard to place her in a neat category - and that turns out to be a source of strength for this eclectic singer/songwriter, Rogers - a member of Ingrid Michaelson's touring band - likes to surround her sweet lyric sentiments with a tough outer coating as she recounts tales of fumbled romance and fragile happiness.
-www.myspace.com/bessrogers
Rachel Platten
Rachel Platten crafts songs with beautiful, memorable melodies and intelligent, moving lyrics. Then she delivers them with her compelling and powerful voice. She is an accomplish guitarist and pianist with enough stage presence to make you forget that anyone else is in the room.
-www.myspace.com/rachelplattenband

event.title: Denison Witmer CD Release Event
event.shortdesc: WXPN Welcomes The Denison Witmer CD Release concert with special guests The Beggar Folk and Mike McMonagle

Lancaster, PA native Denison Witmer returns to his hometown to share a live performance of material from his 8th CD release "The Ones Who Wait." This show will take place in the intimate setting of the Grand Salon on the 3rd floor of Millersville University-Lancaster. Witmer's style has been described as "neo-folk." He has also been compared to 1970s-era singer-songwriters, including Cat Stevens, Jackson Browne and crafts songs in the fashion of Carol King.
Joining Denison, to open the show, will be guest performers; The Beggar Folk and Mike McMonagle.

8:45pm The Beggar Folk: www.myspace.com/thebeggarfolk
9:30pm Denison Witmer: www.denisonwitmer.com

event.title: â€œWilliam Kentridge: Anything is Possibleâ€ Film Screening
event.shortdesc: A screening of "William Kentridge: Anything is Possible," an award-winning documentary, will be held at MU - Lancaster, June 28.

fulldesc.p: Description: Millersville University: South Central Partners presents "William Kentridge: Anything Is Possible," an award-winning documentary that gives viewers an intimate look into the mind and creative process of William Kentridge, the South African artist whose acclaimed charcoal drawings, animations, video installations, shadow plays, mechanical puppets, tapestries, sculptures, live performance pieces and operas have made him one of the most dynamic and exciting contemporary artists working today. The screening, which will be introduced by Joe Fusaro, senior education advisor for Art: 21, will take place Tuesday, June 28, at 7 p.m. at Millersville University-Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster.

This documentary features exclusive interviews with Kentridge as he works in his studio and discusses his artistic philosophy and techniques. In the film, Kentridge talks about how his personal history as a white South African of Jewish heritage has informed recurring themes in his work including violent oppression, class struggle and social and political hierarchies. Additionally, Kentridge discusses his experiments with "machines that tell you what it is to look" and how the very mechanism of vision is a metaphor for "the agency we have, whether we like it or not, to make sense of the world."

The documentary was honored this past March with a prestigious Peabody Award. The Peabody board recognized "William Kentridge: Anything Is Possible" as "a veritable all-access pass to [William Kentridge's] mind and work process" given to Art:21 by an artist whom they describe as "creativity personified" and "a one-man seminar."

With its rich historical references and undertones of political and social commentary, Kentridge's work has earned him inclusion in Time magazine's 2009 list of the 100 most influential people in the world.

"Anything is Possible" was produced by Art:21: Art in the 21st Century, the award wining PBS television series. This event is co-sponsored by Millersville University Department of Art and Design and the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.

Millersville University: South Central PaARTners, an arts-in-education program supported by the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts, a state agency funded by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and the National Endowment for the Arts, a federal agency.
This event is free and open to the public. For more information, contact Tyler Clever, AIE Director, Millersville University: South Central Partners, at Tyler.Clever@millersville.edu or 717-871-2186.

event.title: First Friday in July
event.shortdesc: The artwork of Judy Beck Lobos, music by Matt Bacon and performance by Camp Will's production of The Twelfth Night

fulldesc.p: Description: The Works of Judy Beck Lobos: Judy will have her artwork on display as well as be here in person to meet and greet everyone.

Description: In addition, Matt Bacon, classical guitarist will be playing the Lyet Lobby from 6-8 p.m. Matt's passion for the classical guitar blossomed after meeting and study with renowned teacher and guitarist, Ernesto Tamayo. After completing studies at the Pennsylvania Academy of Music, Matt continued to pursue his interest in music at the Peabody Institute of Johns Hopkins University, where he was a merit scholarship recipient. After graduating from Peabody with honors in 2010, recent accomplishments include a prize in the Texas National Music Festival Classical Minds Competition and an appearance at the Port Deposit Concert Society with internationally recognized organist, Donald Sutherland. As a performer, Matt strives for an organic approach to musical interpretation and audience engagement.

Description: Camp Will's Production of Shakespeare's Twelfth Night. Set in the Caribbean, a one hour version of Shakespeare's rollicking comedy, the "Twelfth Night", featuring middle school students of Camp Will. Doors open at 6:30 p.m. Performance begins at 7 p.m.
All events are free and open to the public.

event.title: First Friday in August
event.shortdesc: First Friday in August brings many events to Millersville University Lancaster

fulldesc.p: Description: Four Corners Art Exhibit "showcasing art works inspired by the 250 years of Millersville's heritage." This First Friday presents Lancaster Veteran's Art Project, Rev9 Dance Group and Singer/Songwriter Amanda Wells.

Lancaster Veteran's Art Project Biography: The Veterans Art Project of Lancaster's purpose is to recognize, support and promote the talents and skills of local veteran visual artists by offering opportunities to display their work.
Rev9 Dance Group Biography: Rev9 Dance Company, a local interdisciplinary dance company to perform excerpts from their new, original production, '77, from 6 p.m. to 8 p.m.

Amanda Wells Biography: Her first guitar was pulled from a dumpster at a construction site where her dad was working and was handed to her after some furniture polish and a mixed set of half used strings. Despite the collection of varied instruments and equipment he owned, her father's knowledge of music consisted of a crude concept of the major scale only in C, and the fingering for basic G, C and F chords. She learned what she could from whoever could teach, and what couldn't be taught, she learned on her own. In October of 2010, Amanda released her first official album Ebb and Flow. The album was recorded at Underground Sound Productions outside of Lancaster, Pennsylvania. The songs are audible illustrations of the memories, trails and triumphs that trace through almost a decade of the singer-songwriter's life.
Ticket Information: All events are FREE and open to the public

event.title: 10th Anniversary of 9/11 Commemoration
event.shortdesc: A commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the September 11th attacks will be among the events held during this yearâ€™s Constitution Week.

fulldesc.p: Description: The Millersville University campus community will come together for a special three-day commemoration of the 10th anniversary of the 9/11/01 attacks, from Sunday, September 11-Tuesday, September 13.
On each of the three days, bells will ring once at 8:46 a.m., twice at 9:03 a.m., three times at 9:37 a.m. and four times at 10:03 a.m., one for each attack that took place on 9/11.

7 p.m. - Service of Remembrance: Reighard Multipurpose Room, Student Memorial Center. Featuring a performace by the United Christian Fellowship Choir and the placement of flags by ROTC and all students in attendance.

8:30 a.m. - Wall of Remembrance: Student Memorial Center. A display of past events (such as a Wall of Remberance created in 2002 during the first anniversary of 9/11) and events of that day will be reflected upon with a slideshow presentation depicting the events of 9/11. Stop by to view all day; to share your reflections, thoughts and prayers, remembering those we lost on that day.

noon - Re-installation of Student Memorial Center plaque and eagle: Student Memorial Center Clock Tower. The plaque and eagle are dedicated to Millersville students who have served our country in the armed forces, law enforcement and public service. This event will feature Dr. Aminta Hawkins-Breaux, vice president for student affairs, and Millersville University's Marching Band.

8:30 a.m. - Wall of Remembrance: Student Memorial Center. A display of past events (such as a Wall of Remberance created in 2002 during the first anniversary of 9/11) and events of that day will be reflected upon with a slideshow presentation depicting the events of 9/11. Stop by to view all day; to share your reflections, thoughts and prayers, remembering those we lost on that day.

5 p.m. - Memorial Service: Reighard Multipurpose Room, Student Memorial Center. A memorial service will be offered to the Millersville University community honoring students and alumni who gave the ultimate sacrifice and dedicated to their surviving family members. This event will feature a flag presentation to Afghanistan casuality and 2008 MU alum LT. Demetrium Frison's wife and family; ROTC Color Guard, a resolution by NAACP, a dance tribute by Brittany McClinton, Bag Pipes procession to the pond and a performance by the Gospel Choir at Millersville University.

On September 14, Michael Parker, senior biology major at Millersville, will present, "So What Did You Do This Summer: The Benefits of REU." Parker is a AMGEN Scholar, ISU-BCB Intern, Samuel Roberts Noble Foundation Intern, Millersville University.

event.title: Reflect and Connect Series: "Our Civility Deficit"
event.shortdesc: The Reflect & Connect Series focuses on a piece of text read by students and faculty that is then discussed by a faculty facilitator.

fulldesc.p: Description: The Reflect & Connect Series is a series of gatherings where community members - faculty, students, staff and residents in the larger community - read short pieces of literature on service, reflect on civic engagement and connect with the community. This year-long series features three meetings each semester. Participants are welcome to join individual sessions or attend them all.

Dr. Gregory Paul, assistant professor in the Department of Communication and Theater, will facilitate the first session on September 14, with "Our Civility Deficit" by Gregory Rodriguez (Los Angeles Times).
Prior to each event, participants register for the session, obtain the reading about civic engagement from Huntington House or through links on Facebook, and read a short (1-3 page) text. At the event, facilitators organize discussion and activities to help participants reflect on the literature as it relates to service and civic engagement. At the end of each meeting, opportunities for getting involved/volunteering/connecting with the community will be discussed.
Ticket Information: Sessions are free and open to the public. Light refreshments will be provided.
For more information on the program, or to register, contact Reflect.Connect@millersville.edu, join our group on Facebook, Reflect & Connect or call 717-872-3776.

event.title: CCERP International Policy Conference: Securing the Future
event.shortdesc: 2011 International Policy Conference Securing the Future: A Global Policy Conference

fulldesc.p: Description: Millersville University's Center for Civic & Community Engagement & Research Project presents the 2011 International Policy Conference: Securing the Future: A Global Policy Conference, September 15-16 in Bolger Conference Center, Gordinier Hall. William "Bill" Richardson, former governor of New Mexico, will present the keynote address on September 15 at 7:30 p.m. in Student Memorial Center.
The conference includes three tracks: The International Status of Women; Global Responses to Genocide and Other Natural Disasters; and Terrorism, Safety and Security.

Schedule of Events/Speakers:
September 15: John Prendergast, 12:15-2:35 p.m.; Aka Strauss, 2:15-4 p.m.; Marta Benavides, 2:15-4 p.m.; Dr. William Lovekamp, 3:45-5:30 p.m. and Dr. Paul Charp, 3:45-5:30 p.m. William "Bill" Richardson, former governor of New Mexico, will present the keynote address on September 15 at 7:30 p.m. Student Memorial Center.
September 16: Nontombi Naomi Tutu, 8:45-10:30 a.m.; Indika Samarawickreme, 10:15 a.m.-noon; Rhoda Margesson, 10:15 a.m.-noon and James Zogby, 11:45 a.m.-2:15 p.m.

Richardson Biography: William "Bill" Richardson III was the 30th Governor of New Mexico (2003-2011). Before being elected governor, Richardson served in the Clinton administration as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations and Energy Secretary. Richardson has also served as a U.S. Congressman, chairman of the 2004 Democratic National Convention and chairman of the Democratic Governors Association. In December of 2008, then-President-elect Barack Obama designated Richardson for appointment to the cabinet-level position of Commerce Secretary. On January 4, 2009, Richardson announced his decision to withdraw his nomination. In 2011, Richardson joined the boards of APCO Worldwide company Global Political Strategies as chairman, the World Resources Institute, the National Institute for Civil Discourse at the University of Arizona and Abengoa (international advisory board). He was also appointed as a special envoy for the Organization of American States.
For additional speaker biographies, visit the Global Policy Conference Website.

event.location: Bolger Conference Center, Gordinier Hall and SMC

All lectures will be given Thursdays from 4:30-5:30 p.m. in Roddy Hall room 149. Light refreshments will be served before the presentation.
Ticket Information: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Humanities Film Series presents: Which Way Home
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series and One Book, One Campus present "Which Way Home"

fulldesc.p: Description: The Humanities Film Series presents a screening of the film Which Way Home by Rebecca Cammisa on September 15 at 7 p.m. in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall. This event will be held in conjunction with the University's One Book, One Campus, which is hosting multiple programs throughout the academic year focused around this year's selection of Enrique's Journey to enrich students.
Discussants: Dr. Kimberly Mahaffy, associate professor and director of Latino Studies and Latino Studies students.

Film Description: As the United States continues to build a wall between itself and Mexico, Which Way Home shows the personal side of immigration through the eyes of children who face harrowing dangers with enormous courage and resourcefulness as they endeavor to make it to the United States.

The film follows several unaccompanied child migrants as they journey through Mexico en route to the U.S. on a freight train they call "The Beast." Director Rebecca Cammisa (Sister Helen) tracks the stories of children like Olga and Freddy, nine-year-old Hondurans who are desperately trying to reach their families in Minnesota, and Jose, a ten-year-old El Salvadoran who has been abandoned by smugglers and ends up alone in a Mexican detention center, and focuses on Kevin, a canny, streetwise 14-year-old Honduran, whose mother hopes that he will reach New York City and send money back to his family. These are stories of hope and courage, disappointment and sorrow. They are the ones you never hear about ­ the invisible ones.
Source: www.whichwayhome.net/about.html.
Ticket Information: This event is FREE and open to the public.

event.title: International Policy Conference Keynote Address: Bill Richardson
event.shortdesc: William "Bill" Richardson, former governor of New Mexico, will present the keynote address during the 2011 International Policy Conference: Securing the Future

fulldesc.p: Description: William "Bill" Richardson, former governor of New Mexico, will present the keynote address during Millersville University's Center for Civic & Community Engagement & Research Project's 2011 International Policy Conference: Securing the Future: A Global Policy Conference, on September 15, at 7:30 p.m. in the Reighard Multipurpose Room, Student Memorial Center.

The two-day conference, from September 15-16, includes three tracks: The International Status of Women; Global Responses to Genocide and Other Natural Disasters; and Terrorism, Safety and Security. For the full schedule of events and speakers, visit the Global Policy Conference Website.

Richardson Biography: William "Bill" Richardson III was the 30th Governor of New Mexico (2003-2010). Before being elected governor, Richardson served in the Clinton administration as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations and Energy Secretary. Richardson has also served as a U.S. Congressman, chairman of the 2004 Democratic National Convention and chairman of the Democratic Governors Association. In 2011, Richardson joined the boards of APCO Worldwide company Global Political Strategies as chairman, the World Resources Institute, the National Institute for Civil Discourse at the University of Arizona and Abengoa (international advisory board). He was also appointed as a special envoy for the Organization of American States.

Ticket Information: This event is free and open to the public; however, tickets are required. Tickets may be picked up at the Student Memorial Center Ticket Office (room 103), or reserved, by calling the Ticket Office at 717-872-3811.

event.title: Concert: An Evening with Plena Libre
event.shortdesc: This 12-piece Puerto Rican band captivates audiences with high-energy rhythms, recording 13 albums and garnering four Grammy nominations.

fulldesc.p: Description: On September 15, at 7:30 p.m., Plena Libre will perform a concert at Millersville University Lancaster. Plena Libre's 15-year history has seen the orchestra re-invent the sound of Puerto Rico's plena and bomba traditions. Along with providing exhilarating entertainment, the orchestra has a deep commitment to educating their audiences about the traditional culture of Puerto Rico.
The concert is sponsored by the Cultural Affairs Committee, Fulton Bank, the Heritage Hotel/Loxley's Restaurant, and the Office of Social Equity & Diversity

event.title: Guest Artist Master Class: Dr. Jennifer Hayghe, piano
event.shortdesc: Millersville University Department of Music Keyboard Symposium presents a master class by Dr. Jennifer Hayghe, pianist.

fulldesc.p: Description: Millersville University's Department of Music Keyboard Symposium presents a master class by guest artist Dr. Jennifer Hayghe, piano. The master class will begin at 3:30 p.m. at Millersville University Lancaster.
Following the master class, at 7:30 p.m., Hayghe will perform a recital.

Biography: Dr. Jennifer Hayghe has performed in solo recitals and made orchestral appearances throughout the world including the United States, Europe and Asia. Hayghe received her bachelor's, master's and doctorate degrees in piano performance from The Juilliard School, where she was the last student of the legendary artist-teacher Adele Marcus. Her first solo recording, Paintings From the Piano, featuring works by Debussy, Schumann and Mussorgksy, was released by Centaur Records. Hayghe has performed and taught as a soloist and chamber musician at universities and colleges throughout the country. Hayghe was the recipient of a 2004 Artists Fellowship from the Louisiana Division of the Arts and was subsequently invited to be on the State Artists Touring Roster.
Ticket Information: The master class event is free and open to the public.

Tickets are required for the 7:30 p.m. recital. Tickets cost $10 general admission, free for students with ID. Tickets may be purchased online, at www.MUTicketsOnline.com, in the Student Memorial Center Ticket Office (Room 103), by calling the Ticket Office, at 717-872-3811 or at Millersville University Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster, Monday through Friday, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

event.title: Series 42 Presents Horse Flies w/ Special guests Vinegar Creek Constituency
event.shortdesc: Series 42 Concert, featuring The Horse Flies with special guest artist Vinegar Creek Constituency.

fulldesc.p: Description: Series 42 Concert, featuring The Horse Flies with special guest artist Vinegar Creek Constituency. Sponsors: Series 42, Music for Everyone, Millersville University Lancaster and WXPN

The Horse Flies Biography: The Horse Flies blend Americana roots with indie rock, ethnic percussion, creative songwriting, and a fierce, percolating groove. With a love of both the traditional and the modern, The Flies have consistently explored the intersection of the two to create a musical world all their own.

Vinegar Creek Contituency Biography: Their American songs are full of deranged old ghosts howling at the moon. Vinegar Creek Constituency, an eclectic, incendiary string band out of the PA Dutch Country, channels these venerable old ghosts of the American folk tradition through imaginative, emotive original songs delivered with rock n roll intensity. Full of shouting, floorboard-stomping soul, their live performances are uplifting, high-energy events with fans dancing in the aisles and clapping, stomping and singing along.
Ticket Information: Tickets are $15 General Admission $12 Students w/ ID. Tickets may be purchased online, at www.MUTicketsOnline.com, in the Student Memorial Center Ticket Office (Room 103), by calling the Ticket Office at 717-872-3811 or at The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St. Lancaster, Monday through Friday, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

event.title: Millersville's 2011 Wellness Fair and Breast-a-Ville
event.shortdesc: The 18th annual Wellness Fair will be celebrated in conjunction with the grand opening of the SMC and the breast health initiative, "Breast-a-Ville" - Both events will be held at Marauder Court

fulldesc.p: Description: Millersville University will hold its 18th annual Wellness Fair Tuesday, Sept. 20, from 11 a.m.-2 p.m. at Marauder Court in the Student Memorial Center (SMC). Celebrated in conjunction with the wellness fair is the grand opening of the SMC and the breast health initiative, "Breast-a-Ville," which will also be held at Marauder Court.

Each year for the fair, a different theme is chosen based on the seven wellness dimensions: physical, social, environmental, spiritual, emotional, occupational and intellectual. This year's theme is physical. There will be many community organizations, Millersville departments and student organizations with interactive displays and activities.

Breast-a-Ville will educate students in many ways about breast health and breast cancer through the interactive event. Young men attending the event will learn and understand that breast cancer does not only affect women, but men, too. Students will learn about breast cancer organizations that offer resources for support, education, research and outreach to communities. Attendees will also benefit from the Breast-a-Ville event when they learn how to take care of themselves with training on how to perform breast self-exams. In addition, there will be community agencies to answer questions, activities and chances to win prizes.
Ticket Information: This event is FREE and open to the public.

event.title: Making It Better: Folk Arts in Pennsylvania Exhibit: Lunchtime Lecture - Yoruba Beadwork and Storytelling
event.shortdesc: A lunchtime lecture series event in conjunction with the Making it Better: Folks Arts in Pennsylvania exhibit

fulldesc.p:
Description: In conjunction with the exhibition Making it Better: Folks Arts in Pennsylvania, running September 12 through October 25 in Sykes Gallery, a series of free lunchtime lectures and demonstrations will be held Wednesdays at noon. On September 21, the lunchtime series will feature Temujin Ekunfeo - Yorbua Beadwork and Storytelling.
Making it Better: Folk Arts in Pennsylvania is an exhibition that tells the stories of more than 30 master artists coming from every corner of Pennsylvania, the art represents a wide array of traditions such as African dance, stone wall construction, Native American flutes, Pysanky eggs, contemporary blacksmith work, woodcarving and Vietnamese funerary portraits.
Lunctime lecture series and demonstration events include:

Sept. 21: Temujin Ekunfeo - Yoruba Beadwork and Storytelling
Sept. 28: Amy Skillman - Curator's Talk
Oct. 12: Pose II - Graffiti
Oct. 19: Losang Samten - Tibetan Mandala Writing
This exhibit and lunchtime lecture series will be held in Sykes Gallery, Breidenstine Hall. Gallery hours are Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sunday, noon-4 p.m. and by appointment.
Ticket Information: All gallery events are free and open to the public.
Free tours of the exhibition may be scheduled by calling Ty Clever, gallery director, at 717-871-2186 or Tyler.Clever@millersville.edu.

event.title: Humanities Film Series presents: Gasland
event.shortdesc: Humanities Film Series presents the film Gasland

fulldesc.p: Description: The Humanities Film Series presents a screening of the film Gasland by director Josh Fox on September 22 at 7 p.m. in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.
Discussant Panel: Drs. Lynn Marquez and Sam Earman, professors of earth sciences, and Dr. John Wallace, professor of biology. With participation from earth sciences classes.

Film Description: "The largest domestic natural gas drilling boom in history has swept across the United States. The Halliburton-developed drilling technology of "fracking" or hydraulic fracturing has unlocked a "Saudia Arabia of natural gas" just beneath us. But is fracking safe? When filmmaker Josh Fox is asked to lease his land for drilling, he embarks on a cross-country odyssey uncovering a trail of secrets, lies and contamination. A recently drilled nearby Pennsylvania town reports that residents are able to light their drinking water on fire. This is just one of the many absurd and astonishing revelations of a new country called GASLAND. Part verite travelogue, part expose, part mystery, part bluegrass banjo meltdown, part showdown." Source: www.gaslandthemovie.com/about-the-film/.

Film Awards: Sundance Film Festival Special Jury Prize, Sarasota International Film Festival Special Jury Prize, Yale Environmental Film Festival Grand Jury Prize, Big Sky Film Festival Artistic Vision Award and Thin Line Film Festival Audience Award.
Ticket Information: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Jazz Series Grand Opening
event.shortdesc: Concert featuring Washington D.C. vocalist Juanita Williams and her trio.

fulldesc.p: Description: The concert will feature Juanita Williams and her trio. The trio accompanying her will be comprised of Fred Hughes on piano, Frank Russo drums, both are also from Washington DC, and Keith Mohler -bass.

Biography: When Juanita Williams released her Grammy nominated debut, "Introducing Juanita Williams," Blues critic Bruce Bjorkman gushed: "What a surprise! What a joy! This girl just reeks with the blues, with a good dose of soul thrown in for good measure with confident, seemingly effortless vocals influenced by such blues greats as Etta James, Ruth Brown and Aretha Franklin. While Williams may draw her inspiration from these notable women of music, she isn't a copycat; she's an original, sashaying from sultry intensity to full-bodied belt-em outs. I want more!"

event.shortdesc: A Music Education Symposium, featuring Ivy Ward at Millersville University Lancaster.

fulldesc.p: Description: A Music Education Symposium, featuring Ivy Rawlins Ward, will be held on September 24 from 9 a.m.-1 p.m. at Millersville University Lancaster.

Biography: Ivy Rawlins Ward has a diploma from the Kodaly Musical Training Institute. She has taught vocal music in the public schools of Washington, D.C., Boston, Hartford and Baltimore. As a faculty member of the Kodaly Musical Training Institute, Holy Names College and the Harrt College of Music she taught methodology, materials and solfege, and supervised student teachers.
Ticket Information: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Community Dialogue: Education on Location - National Issues at Home
event.shortdesc: Millersville's School of Education presents a week-long community dialogue, from September 26-30, on many of the educational system's hottest topics.

fulldesc.p: Description: The School of Education at Millersville University presents "Education on Location - National Issues at Home," a week-long community dialogue from Monday, September 26 through Friday, September 30. Activities will be held throughout the week either at Millersville University or The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster, for the campus and regional communities to discuss issues facing education. There will be sessions in the morning, afternoon and evening to engage and inform about how to help improve education.

p.span: "Education on Location - National Issues at Home" Schedule:

fulldesc.p: Morning - Breakfast 7:30-9 a.m. - Dropout Rate: Why can't we solve this problem? A number of local superintendents join Lynda Becker, MSW, Youth Development Coordinator at Center for Schools and Communities, in a panel discussion on the dropout rate. Location: Stayer Hall, Multipurpose Room.

Afternoon - Vouchers Blog: Will they be the golden ticket or our future albatross? An insightful blog to be posted at Millersville University School of Education Facebook page. Post your comment and keep the discussion going!

Morning - 8-10 a.m. - Focus Groups: Common issues in education. Lancaster Chamber of Commerce will host a breakfast and focus group discussion on common education issues for Lancaster County. Location: Binns Room, The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster. Invitations only by request.

Afternoon - 3-4:30 p.m. - Early Childhood Education: Who needs pre-school? The United Way of Lancaster County will host this discussion. Location: Steinman Hall, The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster. Invitations only by request.

Evening - 6:30 p.m. - Budgets: Local, state & federal equity issues. The Hourglass Foundation will host this panel discussion on the issues with Pa. Secretary of Education Ron Tomalis. Location: The Atrium, The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster. Invitations only by request.

Morning - 7:30 a.m. - Innovation in Education: New forms of teaching (online webcast). Dr. Oliver Dreon, assistant professor of educational foundations and director of the University's Digital Learning Studio, is joined by local teachers to discuss technologies for teaching and learning. This session will be webcast and available for online viewing at the Education on Location homepage.

Afternoon - 3:30 p.m. - Innovation in Education: New forms of teaching (online webcast). A second session by Dr. Onliver Dreon and local teachers discussing technologies for teaching and learning. This session will be webcast and available for online viewing at the Education on Location homepage.

Evening - 6 p.m. - Innovation in Teaching. A presentation by Will Richardson, cofounder of Powerful Learning Practice and author of Blogs, Wikis, Podcasts and Other Powerful Tools for Classrooms. Location: Lehr Room, Bolger Conference Center, Gordinier Hall.
Morning - Stem Blog: Are we still lagging behind? A blog entry to be posted at Millersville University School of Education Facebook page. Post your comment and keep the discussion going!

Afternoon - 4-6 p.m. - Inclusive Classroom: What are we really talking about? A panel discussion with Dr. Ellen Long, assistant professor of special education at Millersville, with local teachers and parents. Location: Stayer Hall, Multipurpose Room.

Evening - 6:30-8 p.m. - Town Hall Meeting - Union Issues: Unions, tenure and teacher effectiveness. A town hall meeting with PSEA President Michael Crossey, Superintendent of Eastern Lancaster County School District Dr. Robert Hollister, Superintendent of Penn Manor School District Dr. Michael Leichliter, and a local teacher. Location: Stayer Hall, Multipurpose Room.

Morning - Breakfast 7:30-9 a.m. - Legislative Breakfast. Millersville University School of Education and the Hourglass Foundation will host a legislative breakfast and panel discussion on educational issues. Location: The Atrium, The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster. Invitations only by request.

Afternoon - Teacher Certification Regulations: What helps, what doesn't help? Lack of flexibility? Master's degrees - Do they or don't they make an impact? Is it worth saving the money? A blog entry to be posted at Millersville University School of Education Facebook page. Post your comment and keep the discussion going!
Ticket information: Select sessions are by invitation only. Contact the School of Education for your invitation at edgradasst@millersville.edu or 717-872-3621.

event.ticketinfo: Select sessions are by invitation only.
event.location: Events will be held at Millersville University or The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St., Lancaster

event.title: Author Talk: Gemma LaSpada
event.shortdesc: Come hear author, MU employee and alum Gemma LaSpada talk about her new book, Angel in Battle

fulldesc.p: Description: Millersville University Library will host their first "Author Talk," featuring Gemma LaSpada, author, Universitylibrary faculty member and alum, on Monday, September 26 from 6-7:30 p.m. During this event, which will be held in the Ford Atrium, McComsey Hall, LaSpada will talk about her new book, Angel in Battle. She will also talk about her writing and publishing process, and what every writer should know before signing a publishing contract.
LaSpada will also hold a book signing; bring your copy of Angel in Battle or purchase one there.

About the book: The future of mankind is in jeopardy. In an ultimate test of faith, people must choose who they will serve - Lucifer or God. Lucifer has waged war with God, seeking nothing less than His throne, and God sends his army of angels to protect His children on Earth. Meanwhile, a young angel named Uriana volunteers to be an Archangel so she may serve God in his fight to the death. Being an angel who is all heart with the spirit to fight for the Almighty, her request is granted. Wounded in battle and her memory lost, Uriana is disguised as a human and given the name Angelina. She is left in the care of devout Christians Jonah Kasthon and Fiona Williams. As Angelina, Uriana must work to regain her memory and identity in time to save mankind from ultimate destruction.
For price and ordering information, visit www.gemmalaspada.com. To view a book trailer, visit www.youtube.com/watch?v=f-ihKrZEmrA.
For more information about the "Author Talk" series, visit www.facebook.edu/ MULibrary and click on "Events." You can also email library.outreach@millersville.edu or call 717-872-3617.
Ticket Information: This event is FREE and open to the public. Light refreshments will be served.

event.ticketinfo: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Humanities Film Series presents: Race to Nowhere - *CANCELED*
event.shortdesc: The Humanities Film Series presents the film Race to Nowhere - THIS EVENT HAS BEEN CANCELED*

fulldesc.p: *THIS EVENT HAS BEEN CANCELED*
Description: The Humanities Film Series presents a screening of the film Race to Nowhere by director Vicki Abeles on September 26 at 7 p.m. in Lehr Room, Bolger Conference Center, Gordinier Hall.
Discussant: TBD

Film Description: Race to Nowhere is a call to mobilize families, educators and policy makers to challenge current assumptions on how to best prepare the youth of America to become healthy, bright, contributing and leading citizens.

In a grassroots sensation already feeding a groundswell for change, hundreds of theaters, schools and organizations nationwide are hosting community screenings during a six-month campaign to screen the film nationwide. Tens of thousands of people are coming together, using the film as the centerpiece for raising awareness, radically changing the national dialogue on education and galvanizing change.
Source: http://www.racetonowhere.com/about-film.
Ticket Information: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: FREE Depression Screening: Session 1
event.shortdesc: Free, anonymous screening for depression for MU students only. Session 1: 11 a.m. -1 p.m.

fulldesc.p: Description: Are you feeling angry, depressed or anxious? Millersville University's Center for Counseling and Human Development invites Millersville students to participate in a free, anonymous screening for depression on September 28. The screening, which is being held in conjunction with National Depression Screening Day (screening for mental health), will take place in the Counseling Center, located on the third floor of Lyle Hall. Day and evening screenings will be held as follows:

Session 1: 11 a.m. - 1 p.m.
Session 2: 4-6 p.m.
Students will view a brief video, complete a depression assessment instrument and review the results of their assessment with a mental health professional.

p.strong: No appointment necessary; all services are strictly confidential.

fulldesc.p: For more information, contact the Counseling Center at 717-872-3122.

link.name: Center for Counseling and Human Development

event.title: Making It Better: Folk Arts in Pennsylvania Exhibit: Lunchtime Lecture - Amy Skillman, Curator's Talk
event.shortdesc: A lunchtime lecture series event in conjunction with the Making it Better: Folks Arts in Pennsylvania exhibit

fulldesc.p: Description: In conjunction with the exhibition Making it Better: Folks Arts in Pennsylvania, running September 12 through October 25 in Sykes Gallery, a series of free lunchtime lectures and demonstrations will be held Wednesdays at noon. On September 28, the lunchtime lecture series will feature Amy Skillman presenting a curator's talk.

Making it Better: Folk Arts in Pennsylvania is an exhibition that tells the stories of more than 30 master artists coming from every corner of Pennsylvania; the art represents a wide array of traditions such as African dance, stone wall construction, Native American flutes, Pysanky eggs, contemporary blacksmith work, woodcarving and Vietnamese funerary portraits.
Lunctime lecture series and demonstration events include:

Sept. 21: Temujin Ekunfeo - Yoruba Beadwork and Storytelling
Sept. 28: Amy Skillman - Curator's Talk
Oct. 12: Pose II - Graffiti
Oct. 19: Losang Samten - Tibetan Mandala Writing
This exhibit and lunchtime lecture series will be held in Sykes Gallery, Breidenstine Hall. Gallery hours are Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sunday, noon-4 p.m. and by appointment.
Ticket Information: All gallery events are free and open to the public.
Free tours of the exhibition may be scheduled by calling Ty Clever, gallery director, at 717-871-2186 or Tyler.Clever@millersville.edu.

event.ticketinfo: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Melva S McIlwaine Music Master Class - Robert Bokor, violin
event.shortdesc: The Lancaster Symphony Orchestra presents Robert Bokor, violin, at MU Lancaster on September 28, 2011 at 3:30 p.m.

fulldesc.p: Description: The master class program at Millersville University partners with the Lancaster Symphony Orchestra to bring world-renowned guest musicians to campus to interact with music students. Guest artists are invited to critique several student performances and guide them as performing musicians. Students are selected by faculty to perform for the guest artists, who offer insights into performing music repertoire.

Biography: Serbian conductor and violinist, Bokor is Chief Conductor of the Austrian Arpeggione Chamber Orchestra and serves as Artistic Director of the Belgrade Philharmonic Orchestra. He studied at the Belgrade University of the Arts and won numerous awards and competitions, as well as appearing on radio and television broadcasts. Bokor has appeared with orchestras throughout Europe, Israel, Asia, South and Central America and the USA and is a strong advocate of contemporary music, with his concert appearances including many world premieres of new works dedicated to him.
Ticket Information: This event is FREE and open to the public.

event.location: Steinman Hall, The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster, 42 N. Prince St.

event.title: Humanities Film Series presents: Leave Them Laughing
event.shortdesc: The Humanities Film Series presents the film Leave Them Laughing

fulldesc.p: Description: The Humanities Film Series presents a screening of the film Leave Them Laughing by director John Zaritsky on September 29 at 7 p.m. in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.
Discussant: Dr. Tom Neuville, associate professor of special education, with special education students.

Film Description: Once a nationally known performer of ballads, skits and self-parody, now fated by Lou Gehrig's Disease to perish within months, the remarkable Carla Zilbersmith was diagnosed in 2007 and given less than four years to live. She will leave a teen-aged son, a few fans and students who adore her, and this 90-minute pre-mortem retrospective of a life lived fully, but far too fast. Source: www.leavethemlaughingfilm.com/blog/about-the-film/.
Film Awards: Winner of Special Jury Award (Canadian Feature) and Top Ten Audience Award at Hot Docs 2010 (May 2010).
Ticket Information: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Library Outreach Film Screening: Bad Day to Go Fishing
event.shortdesc: Millersville University's Library will present two award winning foreign films at its foreign film screening

fulldesc.p: Description: Millersville University Library will present two award-winning foreign films at its foreign film screening. Bad Day to Go Fishing will be presented at 7 p.m. and A Call Girl will be presented at 9 p.m. The foreign film screenings are co-sponsored by MU's Foreign Language Department and the MU Cine Club.

Bad Day to Go Fishing: Jacob van Oppen, formerly "the strongest man on earth" and now a washed up alcoholic, and his crafty manager, Orsini, make good money staging bogus wrestling matches in small South American towns. When this oddball duo arrives in the unassuming village of Santa Maria, business really takes off. The local newspaper sponsors the fight, and the quiet hamlet becomes plastered with posters announcing an open challenge to a worthy adversary. The ever-resourceful Orsini is sure he can find the right opponent to throw the fight, but fishing in Santa Maria yields a bigger catch than he'd hoped for. WINNER Best Actor, Mar del Plata International Film Festival; Best Supporting Actor, Slovene Film Festival.
A Call Girl: Having grown up in small-town Slovenia, 23-year-old Alexandra embraces the excitement and anonymity of big city life when she moves to the capital. She styles herself as a call girl, planning to take advantage of everything the city has to offer. But her isolated existence — English studies and mortgage payments by day, call girl lifestyle by night — is shattered when one of her clients, a visiting politician, dies of a heart attack on her watch. Alexandra must suddenly confront fear, guilt, and desperation as she finds herself pursued by a band of local pimps, as well the cops, hot on her trail. The old village life she had escaped from might now become her only refuge. WINNER Best Actress (Nina Ivanišin), Valencia Film Festival of Mediterranean Cinema; Best Supporting Actor, Slovene Film Festival.
Ticket information: This event is FREE and open to the public.

event.title: Dance & Music by Dr. Lynn Brooks
event.shortdesc: "Dance & Music: Improvisation & Collaboration" Lecture/Performance by Dr. Lynn Brooks

fulldesc.p: Description: What does "improvisation" mean? Experienced improvisers in the arts of dance and music discuss and demonstrate some of the intentions, materials, and structures with which artists work when creating improvised performances - both when working in each art individually and when these two sister arts are improvised together. These lecture-demonstrations will feature performance discussion, and questions from the audience presented by Lynn Brooks, m.c. (faculty, F&M College).
Ticket Information: Tickets are $10 and free for students with ID.

event.location: The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster, 42 North Prince Street, Lancaster, PA 17603

event.title: PRIMA Theatre Presents "Chess"
event.shortdesc: Chess is a musical by two songwriters formerly with ABBA and lyrics by Tim Rice involving a romantic triangle within the setting of an international chess championship.

fulldesc.p: Description: Chess is a musical story involving a romantic triangle between two top players, an American and a Russian, in a world chess championship. A woman who manages one player falls in love with the other; all in the context of a Cold War struggle between the United States and the Soviet Union during a time when both countries were competing on the international chess stage for propaganda purposes. The first theatrical production of Chess opened in London's West End in 1986 and played for three years. This is a partially staged, concert version. Chess will also be presented on October 9 and 16, at 7:30 p.m.
Ticket Information: Tickets are $22 and up. Tickets are available at www.primatheatre.com

event.title: The Amish and the Media Lecture
event.shortdesc: "The Amish and the Media: Lessons from Nickel Mines" -- a Lecture by Dr. Diane Umble with an Exhibit of the Amish by Photographer Bill Martin

fulldesc.p: Description: Dr. Diane Umble, a specialist on the Amish community analyzes how the Amish dealt with the very public, national media during the famous Nickel Mine School Tragedy during which several children were killed. Umble examines the Amish ability to forgive under daunting circumstances and extracts lessons we can all learn from that terrible tragedy. This lecture is accompanied by a very special exhibit of the black and white photographs of the Amish Community by the late Bill Martin. This event is sponsored by The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster, Rodgers & Associates and co-sponsored by Ann Barshinger.
Ticket Information: Tickets are $15 or free for students with ID.

event.title: Humanities Film Series presents: Exit Through the Gift Shop
event.shortdesc: The Humanities Film Series presents a screening of the film Exit Through the Gift Shop on October 6 at 7 p.m. in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.

fulldesc.p: Description: The Humanities Film Series presents a screening of the film "Exit Through the Gift Shop," on October 6 at 7 p.m. in Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall.
Discussant: Ty Clever, arts in education coordinator and AIE program director for South Central PaARTners), with Anne Kirby, Creative House of Lancaster, and Millersville art students.

Film description: This is the inside story of Street Art - a brutal and revealing account of what happens when fame, money and vandalism collide. Exit Through the Gift Shop follows an eccentric shop-keeper turned amateur film-maker as he attempts to capture many of the world's most infamous vandals on camera, only to have a British stencil artist named Banksy turn the camcorder back on its owner with wildly unexpected results. Source: www.banksyfilm.com/synopsis.html?reload.

Film awards: Best documentary - 2010 Independent Spirit Awards; Best documentary (runner-up) - 2010 L.A. Film Critics Association; Best non-fiction film (runner-up) - 2010 National Society of Film Critics.
Ticket Information: This event is free and open to the public.

event.ticketinfo: This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Carter G. Woodson Lecture: Charles Dutton - "From Jail to Yale"
event.shortdesc: Carter G. Woodson Lecture with Charles Dutton, Emmy Award-Winning Actor and Director

fulldesc.p: Description: Charles Dutton, Emmy award-wining actor and director will present the Carter G. Woodson Lecture on October 6 at 7:30 p.m. His lecture, titled, "From Jail to Yale," will be held at Bright Side Baptist Church, 515 Hershey Ave., Lancaster. Free buses from SMC every 10 minutes from 6:30 to 7:30 p.m. Return buses begin at 9 p.m.

Biography: Best known for his starring role as "Roc" as well as Emmy-winning guest roles in "The Practice" and "Without a Trace," Dutton, a graduate of Yale, worked with acclaimed playwright August Wilson. He appeared in Wilson's "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom" and "The Piano Lesson," both of which earned him Tony nominations. He also starred in Wilson's Pulitzer Prize-winning play, "Joe Turner's Come and Gone." His directing credits include feature film "Against the Ropes," miniseries "The Corner" and television movie "First Time Felon."
Ticket Information: This event is FREE and open to the public.

event.shortdesc: Carvel Markley wowed local art aficionados with his last very eclectic, mixed media art exhibit in February, 2011. This exhibit showcases his schnittes (hand-cut, lace-like images) and striking computer manipulated floral images.

fulldesc.p: Description: Carvel Markley is showcasing two new sides of his work during this exhibit. He is presenting schnittes (hand-cut, lace-like images) and striking computer manipulated floral images. These artworks must be seen to be believed and all are for sale this time around. The Markley exhibit will be on display from October 7-30. The exhibit is sponsored by The Ware Center at MU Lancaster & Rodgers & Associates.

event.title: The Works of Chad Buffington
event.shortdesc: Chad Buffington has worked in various media including watercolor, oil and pencil. Chad's work often captures the beauty of the Amish countryside, animals and local institutions like the Fulton Theatre.

fulldesc.p: Description: Chad Buffington's work is dramatically realistic with painstaking attention to detail. His exhibit will be on display from October 7-30 at The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster.

Biography: Buffington has won the People's choice award for best original in the Lancaster County Art Association's Holiday Show for three years in a row. In addition to his many accomplishments, he was also commissioned to paint the cover art for the book entitled "Dear Coach: Letters Home From the War" written by Lois Herr, published in the fall of 2009. Buffington is an active member of the Pennsylvania Watercolor Society, Lancaster County Art Association and Chester County Art Association.
Ticket Information: Free and open to the public.

event.title: The Works of Cynthia Lee
event.shortdesc: Cynthia Lee's breathtaking, large color paintings depicting cloud-filled skies and huge florals will be displayed.

fulldesc.p: Description: Cynthia Lee's large color paintings depicting cloud-filled skies and huge florals will be displayed at The Ware Center at Millersville University Lancaster from October 7-30.

Biography: Cynthia Lee is a professional visual artist who's primary medium is oil paint on stretched canvas. She began her painting in oils at age 10 when she studied at a neighbor's studio in group classes. Lee attended Moor College of Art in Philadelphia, received a BA in Art History from Franklin & Marshall College and continued her education through the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, The Arts Extension Service and the National Assembly of Local Art Agencies. She is best know for her contemporary large format florals and landscapes however her capacity as an artist is wide. A 10th generation Lancastrian, Lee has a strong commitment to community development and civic engagement through her art initiatives.
Ticket Information: Free and open to the public.

event.shortdesc: A lunchtime lecture series event in conjunction with the Making it Better: Folks Arts in Pennsylvania exhibit

fulldesc.p: Description: In conjunction with the exhibition Making it Better: Folks Arts in Pennsylvania, running September 12 through October 25 in Sykes Gallery, a series of free lunchtime lectures and demonstrations will be held Wednesdays at noon. On October 12, the lunchtime lecture series will features Pose II, Grafitti.

Making it Better: Folk Arts in Pennsylvania is an exhibition that tells the stories of more than 30 master artists coming from every corner of Pennsylvania, the art represents a wide array of traditions such as African dance, stone wall construction, Native American flutes, Pysanky eggs, contemporary blacksmith work, woodcarving and Vietnamese funerary portraits.
Lunctime lecture series and demonstration events include:

Sept. 21: Temujin Ekunfeo - Yoruba Beadwork and Storytelling
Sept. 28: Amy Skillman - Curator's Talk
Oct. 12: Pose II - Graffiti
Oct. 19: Losang Samten - Tibetan Mandala Writing
This exhibit and lunchtime lecture series will be held in Sykes Gallery, Breidenstine Hall. Gallery hours are Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sunday, noon-4 p.m. and by appointment.
Ticket Information: All gallery events are free and open to the public.

event.title: Guest Artist Master Class: Eduardo Chama, international Bass-Baritone
event.shortdesc: Millersville University's Department of Music Voice Symposium welcomes Eduardo Chama, international Bass-Baritone to present a Master Class.

fulldesc.p: Description: Millersville University Department of Music Voice Symposium welcomes Eduardo Chama, international Bass-Baritone to present a Master Class.

Biography: Bass-baritone Eduardo Chama has received resounding recognition for his work on both the operatic and concert stages of the world. Eduardo Chama's engagements for the 2010-11 season currently include the role of Sancho Panza in Massenet's Don Quichotte with both Teatro Massimo in Palermo and Seattle Opera and Bartolo in Il barbiere di Siviglia with Grand Theatre de Geneve. In the 2009-10 season Chama sang Sancho Panza in Don Quichotte with Tulsa Opera, Don Magnifico in La Cenerentola under the baton of Anthony Walker with Washington Concert Opera, Leporello in Don Giovanni with Teatro Colon and the title role in Falstaff in a return to Seattle Opera.
Ticket Information: This event is FREE and open to the public.
